newsitem.title: MEXICO: Mexico blue chip gains weighed by auction forecast.
newsitem.headline: Mexico blue chip gains weighed by auction forecast.

text.p: Mexican stocks ended mixed Tuesday, with blue chips advancing, but the broad market was kept down by forecast hikes in domestic interest rates, traders and analysts said.
Blue chip stocks gained amid a recovery from profit taking Monday and solid gains by the Dow Jones industrial average.
"The market is firm but awaiting the primary auction, and awaiting what happens with the peso," said Gerardo Copca, an analyst with the Finamex brokerage.
The blue-chip IPC index rose 16.62 points, or 0.40 percent, to 4,142.92.
In the broad market, 44 stocks gained, 44 fell and 22 closed unchanged. Trading volume was moderate at 80.5 million shares.
In New York, the Dow Jones industrial average soared 60.77 points to close at 7,539.27.
A Reuters survey of nine money market dealers predicted Banco de Mexico would assign bellwether 28-day Cetes, or treasury bonds, at an average of 20.77 percent, up 147 basis points.
"The Dow did not influence the bourse as much as we would have liked, but the fact it gained does help us," Copca added.
Telmex recovered from profit taking Monday, traders said, to gain 2 centavos (less than 1 cent) to 18.64 pesos ($2.34).

The telecommunications stock accounted for 15 percent of all shares traded on the exchange and contributed most to market gains. Telmex American Depository Receipts, meanwhile, ended unchanged at $46.875.
Retailer Cifra also helped drive the market, up 36 centavos (5 cents) to 13.32 pesos ($1.67).
"They hit Cifra hard yesterday, and it recovered, but opinions are still very mixed on what last week's merger agreement with Wal-Mart will mean for the company," a desk trader said.
Dealers noted that Bancomer, one of Mexico's largest financial groups, managed to fend off the potentially adverse effect of the expected Cetes rate increases.
Bancomer B shares ended unchanged at 3.37 pesos (42 cents) after brisk trade. The A series also closed unchanged at 1.87 pesos (23 cents).
Tortilla and corn flour maker Maseca ended near the top of the prominent gainers' list.
Maseca climbed 30 centavos (4 cents) to 7.90 pesos (99 cents) following news of a modified government scheme of price subsidies for tortillas, which are a staple of the traditional Mexican diet.
